11.09pm GMT

Now it's time to watch the results come in – and we have a blog for that. Head on over to our live election night coverage with Richard Adams, who is sticking with this thing till it sinks.

Updated at 11.15pm GMT

11.04pm GMT

Summary

• A large, possibly record number of voters are turning out in Florida, Virginia and perhaps elsewhere. Long lines formed in Ohio. Americans apparently love voting.

• Voting irregularities have been reported in Pennsylvania, where signs misleadingly demand that voters show ID. Multiple complaints with voting machines have surfaced. At other polling stations there was nothing to see here.

• Governor Mitt Romney visited campaign volunteers in Cleveland and Pennsylvania before landing in Boston to watch the results come in. President Obama won his election day basketball game by about 20 points, did a bunch of radio interviews and worked the phones.

• Our correspondents have spoken with voters and taken the measure of the race at polling stations in the battleground states of Virginia, Florida, New Hampshire, Ohio, Iowa, Wisconsin, Colorado and Nevada.

• Preliminary exit poll results from the Associated Press indicate that the economy remained the top concern for voters.

10.48pm GMT

Obama jumps in on Reddit to get out the vote

Just a bit ago, President Obama peeked in on a Reddit Politics thread and urged people to vote.

"I want to thank you all again for the reception you gave me in August for my AMA," he wrote. "Good questions. Definitely not bad. I'm checking in because polls will start closing in this election in just a few hours, and I need you to vote."

You can view the rest of Obama's comment – in which he equates spreading the word with "upvoting" – here.

The site hasn't crashed. Yet.

Katie Rogers

Updated at 10.49pm GMT

10.43pm GMT

Jim Newell visits a polling station in Fairfax, Virginia, to find a bunch of really helpful people and hardly any mischief afoot:

The paranoia is pervasive, everywhere. Who will robocall what lie, what machine will break, who will steal the election in any of the few remaining battleground states? One YouTube of a voting machine not registering someone's Obama vote, and everyone's on edge all day.

In Fairfax, Virginia, the largest county in the state that sits along the red-blue line dividing "Old Virginia" – Southern, white – from "New Virginia" – young people, professionals, yuppies, minorities, and other non-Real Americans – the elementary schools that serve as polling stations are enveloped in surveillance. What if there's some kind of organized racket or voting machine issue that screws up the tally in one of the most important counties in the country? It would only be surprising if someone didn't give it a shot.

So that's why outside of Mosby Woods School in the residential town of Vienna, Virginia, the end of the DC Metro's Orange subway line, we weren't the only ones waiting to badger voters as they tried to perform their civic duty in peace and quiet.

Three Republican party volunteers greeted all incoming voters with sample-ballots. Voters were then handed off to an Asian-American voters' activist, who ensured that members of this large international community in Fairfax had everything in order and understood where they needed to go.

Two poll watchers, at the door, and more along the way, through the long line that was about to get much longer as the workday ended.

And then, when they exited, two other Asian-American voters' activists offering surveys in at least Chinese and Korean – one voter requested Tibetan – followed by a voting machine monitor to keep track of malfunctions, and lastly, a Guardian reporter asking them personal questions about their politics, for publication.

We chose to visit Mosby Woods after reading an early-day blurb about a voting machine failure there. Was this a scandalous failure, designed to suppress the Asian-American vote which went 62% nationally for President Obama in 2008? Was someone stealing the election at this very elementary school?

Nope. The voting machine monitor explained that the thing just had a glitch, or stalled for a minute. It slowed down the process, briefly, but the flow of voters resumed shortly afterwards. Not a big deal, at all.

Now where's the fun in that, when every glitch reported across the country doesn't turn out to be a breathtaking scandal?

Jim Newell

Updated at 10.43pm GMT

10.34pm GMT

What happened to the supposed falloff in voter enthusiasm from 2008? Both Florida and Virginia are reporting what is being called "record" turnout:

10.27pm GMT

Economy is top issue in AP preliminary exit polls

Preliminary results of an exit poll conducted for The Associated Press show that the presidential election hinges once again on the economy.

And here we would like to return to a public service announcement on behalf of the Committee To Avoid Exit Poll Madness that The Guardian's Richard Adams made last night. Listen to these wise words:

"Friends don't let friends tweet or email exit polls," Richard advises. "Rewind to 2004 if you don't believe me."

The AP exit polls in question, in any case, don't land on a conclusion likely to upend anyone's world view:

The survey of voters as they leave polling places Tuesday shows 6 in 10 voters say the economy is the top issue facing the nation, with unemployment and rising prices hitting voters hard.

About 4 in 10 say they think the nation's economy is on the mend, but more say that things are getting worse or are bad and stagnating.

Updated at 10.28pm GMT

10.14pm GMT

First polls close in less than one hour

It won't be long now: the first polls close in Kentucky and Indiana in just under an hour, at 6pm ET. (Some polling stations in those states, which straddle time zones, stay open till 7pm.) Both states fall solidly into the Romney column.

Polling stations in Virginia are scheduled to close at 7pm ET, although the long lines we're seeing reported there could mean that polls stay open a bit longer, or that the results will post later.

Ohio closes at 7.30 pm ET, but we're not likely to know those numbers until late tonight. Pennsylvania winds down at 8pm ET. All poll closing times here.

Below is our US elections print-out guide with all the polling times you need – and a lot more, including electoral votes and polling averages. Click here for an enlarged image.

Updated at 10.36pm GMT

10.04pm GMT

Obama wins – at basketball

In Obama’s basketball game, the president naturally was the player-coach of his side. Naturally, he also won.

Those who have participated in these games in the past say it should not be assumed that the president is always allowed to win and insisted the games are extremely competitive.

One of those who played today, Alexi Ginnoulias, the former Illinois state treasurer who played on Obama’s side, offered some details to a White House pool reporter.

The game was five-on-five with 12-minute quarters. The president’s team won by about 20, with a score, he said, “like 102, 105, 108 or so to 80-something.”

Well, that’s at least one victory today.

Ewen MacAskill

But wait – he had Pippen?!?

Updated at 10.04pm GMT

9.50pm GMT

International observers keep distance from polls in Texas

The Guardian's Tom Dart is in Houston, Texas, where international election observers have deployed to keep an eye on today's voting:

Observers in Texas are keeping their distance from polling stations after the state's attorney general threatened them with arrest.

Greg Abbott sent a letter to the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe last month warning the group that its observers could be charged with a criminal offence if they violate state anti-loitering laws by coming within 100 feet of a polling place.

Abbott, a Republican, is apparently offended that OSCE had met with groups that oppose voter ID laws. Texas' attempts to pass an ID law have so far been blocked by federal judges. Tougher identity requirements would be likely to reduce turnout among the elderly, black and Hispanic voters: groups that typically support Democrats.

When an OSCE official wrote to Secretary of State Hillary Clinton to complain about the warning, Abbott tweeted: "My response: BRING IT". He wrote to the State Department to tell them that no one messes with
Texas elections. His stance was backed by Texas governor Rick Perry.

Iowa joined in last week, telling OSCE to stay 300 feet away from polling sites.

Rather than risk an international incident, the OSCE has decided its
two Texas monitors will not try to enter any stations, making their
presence appear rather futile.

"We comply with legislation as it's in effect in that jurisdiction," a
spokesman for OSCE told the Guardian. "Examining what happens in
polling stations on the day in Texas will not be possible ... [but]
the process is much more than election day."

Based in Vienna, the OSCE has 56 participating states, including the
US. It has sent observers to witness US elections in states including
Texas since 2002 without incident – though not always without friction.

Tom Dart

9.41pm GMT

That malfunctioning voting machine video we posted earlier appears not to have been an isolated incident. News outlets and voter rights groups are amassing reports of voting problems across the country.

In Greensboro, N.C., voters reported that touchscreen machines switched their votes from Romney to Obama. On Friday, the Colorado secretary of state's office said it was looking into claims made by the Pueblo County's Republican party that their touchscreens were doing the same thing.

The problems aren't isolated to the screens flubbing voter attempts to pick a presidential candidate. In Virginia Beach Tuesday, a voter sent a video of a touchscreen failing to register either YES or NO votes for a proposed light rail referendum for the city.

As many as 25 percent of Americans this year will vote on machines with no voter-verifiable paper record, according to VerifiedVoting.org.

The Daily Beast has created an online mailform voters can use to report problems. Mother Jones is mapping reported cases of voter difficulties.

Katie Rogers

Updated at 9.42pm GMT

9.32pm GMT

Wisconsin TV reporter Jessica Arp has posted a photo from within Chicago's cavernous McCormick Place, the site of tonight's Obama celebration or commiseration party:

The weather in Chicago is a balmy 40 degrees, complete with rain – perhaps one reason why the city's 70,000-capacity Grant Park won't reprise its 2008 appearance as Obama's speech venue.

Katie Rogers

Updated at 9.33pm GMT

9.25pm GMT

The Guardian's Alexander Hotz is on Staten Island, New York, in one the areas hit hardest by Hurricane Sandy. In the Midland neighborhood he finds four large white tents set up as a makeshift polling station outside a public school with no power. The election machines were being powered by generators:

Amidst the hum of generators and the noise from a nearby Con Edison crew replacing damaged power lines, Ann Marie Lotz recounted how her 95-year-old mother had lost everything in the storm.

"Her living space was totally immersed in 15 feet of water," said Lotz. "But she had to come out and vote."

Lotz's mother had trouble hearing this reporter over the din, but she said she felt she had to vote because, "I love America."

Virgina Glasser, 55, said she was voting for President Obama. Glasser had moved to Midland with her cat temporarily to live with her brother since her home in Long Island had no power or heat.

"I'm glad Governor Cuomo has allowed displaced voters to vote anywhere in the state," said Glasser, referring to the governor's recent proclamation. "It's a huge help."

Although several residents criticized what they said was a slow state and federal response to the storm, Gabriel Rivera, 33, a New York City cop, said he thought the government had been "fair."

Rivera said he lost everything in Sandy, including his home and two cars. Although he wouldn't say who he was voting for, he said he was thankful for FEMA and had applied to the agency for reimbursements.

"I think the storm brought us closer together, New Yorkers and the nation," said Rivera. "It's made me more thankful for the things I have. Property can be replaced, loved ones can't."

Alexander Hotz

Updated at 9.27pm GMT

9.16pm GMT

Yesterday we asked you to play Mad Libs and tell us what you'll do if your candidate loses tonight.

Ruth Spencer has selected some of her favorite responses, including these:

"If Romney wins I will … buy a bunker. If Obama wins I will … buy gold."

"If Romney wins I will … be so confused with humanity that I will decide to live as a duck."

and many others you can check out here.

9.13pm GMT

The Guardian's Adam Gabbatt visits a polling station in Concord, New Hampshire:

I've been speaking to voters in the New Hampshire city of Concord, specifically Ward 2 in the city, at the West Congregational Church. Obama held a rally here with Bill Clinton on Sunday, by the State Capitol in downtown Concord. Will that be enough to swing voters?

Adam Gabbatt

8.58pm GMT

Man 'dies' at polling station, revives and asks: 'Did I vote?'

From the department of couldn't-make-that-up, a report in The Detroit News, in which Ty Houston, 48, a home care registered nurse, went to vote and ended up administering CPR to an elderly man who collapsed while voting:

"He was dead," Houston said. "He had no heartbeat and he wasn't breathing. I started CPR, and after a few minutes, he revived and started breathing again. He knew his name and his wife's name."

What happened next astounded Houston and the victim's wife.

"The first question he asked was 'Did I vote?'"

(h/t @ByronTau)

Updated at 8.58pm GMT

8.52pm GMT

Supporters of Governor Mitt Romney lined a parking lot to greet the candidate's plane in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania:

8.48pm GMT

This Post headline sounds like Watergate redux: Report: Break-in at Democratic headquarters in Washington

Hang on – that would be Washington state. Not the national capital. Still:

According to reports from Seattle, the Washington state Democrats said someone broke into their campaign headquarters Monday night. Brian M. Rosenthal, a Seattle Times reporter, wrote on Twitter that the office was the state headquarters for President Obama’s and Washington state gubernatorial candidate Jay Inslee’s campaigns.

(h/t: @AntDeRosa)

Updated at 9.28pm GMT

8.40pm GMT

The Guardian's Paul Harris is in central Iowa, where he meets the voter the Obama campaign fears:

Iowa school teacher Carleen Coppock is about as close to a demographic nightmare for the Obama campaign as it is possible to get. She is a woman (obviously), she voted for Obama in 2008 and she’s a registered independent in a vital swing state. So who did she vote for and why?

“Romney. The economy,” she said with no hesitation when asked after she emerged from the voting booth in the small central Iowa town of Pella.

She feels let down by the promises of four years ago and – more importantly – says she did not get the impression Obama had much of a plan for the next four years. She worries that her kids won’t have a future as good as her past. “It is the children thing mainly,” said the 40-year-old.

“I have a daughter about to go to college and I want her to have a job when she comes out.” She said she drifted towards Romney over the summer and then the first debate settled her mind. "That about did it. I started leaning Romney," she said.

There are some Obama fans here, like John Phillybrook, 41 years old and a local software engineer. “I voted for Barack Obama,” he said after coming out of a branch of the American Legion which was serving as a polling place. “I just do not believe anything Mitt Romney says. He says he is going to create all these jobs but those are just promises to get elected. The Republicans always say things like that,” he explained before going off to finish his lunch break and heading back to work.

But beneath Pella’s quaint small town exterior there do lurk some ugly political leanings. Shirley Schutte, 75 and retired, has a simple reason why she voted for Romney over Obama. “Obama is a Muslim,” she said bluntly. When asked if she was sure about that, she did not budge. “I am. I am not sure he even should have been there (in the White House). He has been a disaster,” she said.

Paul Harris

8.30pm GMT

Four words that rewrote history?

The Plum Line's Greg Sargent echoes 538 pollster Nate Silver, who wrote yesterday that "the pivotal moment of the 2012 presidential race may have actually occurred in 2009," when President Obama set the terms of the federal bailout of GM and Chrysler.

In November 2008, Governor Romney took a stand against the bailout. He wrote a Times editorial arguing for a "managed bankruptcy" for the auto industry. He wrote:

The American auto industry is vital to our national interest as an employer and as a hub for manufacturing. A managed bankruptcy may be the only path to the fundamental restructuring the industry needs.

The editorial ran under a headline that Romney has not been able to get away from – and one that may have, should Romney lose the election, cost him Ohio:

8.22pm GMT

Our Daniel Hernandez visits a polling station on the east side of Las Vegas, Nevada:

A social worker named Emi Horiai, 26, said she supports Barack Obama. "I work with homeless teens," Horiai said. "There are a lot that come in and they become pregnant and I want to make sure they continue to have a choice whether they’re going to keep the child or not. I respect the value of life. I really share the same value, but I feel like we should have the right to choose how we want to go with our lives.”

Marilyn Louden, 69, a retired government worker, voted for Mitt Romney. She described the research she did on the president's Kenya roots: “This was the 12th presidential election I voted in, going back to Kennedy,” she said. “I did a lot of background research on Barack Obama, one of them being ‘Obama 2016.’ We voted for somebody four years ago that we had no background on. The movie looks at his mentors in college, what was his father about. It goes to Hawaii, to Indonesia, to Kenya. Probably the biggest part of the movie was when they talked to Obama’s half brother over there.
 
“I’ve worked with lots of Filipinos, blacks, whites, seniors – and the biggest fear that I have is we’re not educating people to our American way. I talked to a couple the other day that could barely speak English, and they’re out for Obama. They really don’t know what America is about.”

8.15pm GMT

Our journalistic brethren have created some excellent election day products, and the Guardian's Amanda Holpuch has put together a best-of-the-best list for you to consult:

The Washington Post has a nifty interactive where users can make their own "I voted" buttons with a small slot to explain why they picked who they did.

Mother Jones compiled a quick hit list of campaign money stats on the most expensive election in US history. The magazine has also put together an unfortunately necessary interactive map that collects voter suppression and polling problems across the country.

ProPublica has a handy guide that explains why you might want to hold off on Instagramming your ballot.

A bit of salty language is used to help the electorate with one of the most important parts of the election, figuring out where to vote.

NPR's homepage for election coverage has a clear numerical breakdown and nice back channel of posts on the election that is a little more tidy that your Twitter feed.

The New York Times dropped its paywall today for the election and they've got a 512 paths to the White House interactive that shows all paths to victory possible for each candidate. They have also made the most comprehensive guide to key ballot measures in each state. For a more specific guide to your home state, local news organizations have the best information.

Finally, America's top satirical newssource, The Onion, has joined the live blog arena, contributing faux-headlines such as: "Man Who Eats Breakfast At Dunkin' Donuts Every Morning And Enjoys The ‘Saw’ Films Allowed To Vote."

Facebook has a real-time map that lights up the country as the site's users share who they voted for on their profiles. More than 4 million people's votes are counted on the map and it breaks down the votes by age.

Updated at 9.55pm GMT

8.04pm GMT

Governor Mitt Romney and running mate Paul Ryan have touched down in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. Below is a snapshot of their earlier stop in Cleveland, where they thanked the troops. MSNBC reports that the Republican ticket hit a Wendy's before leaving Ohio, and that the governor consumed a Frosty.

7.56pm GMT

Polls show that Governor Mitt Romney's luck has run out, writes Guardian US forecaster Harry Enten:

It now seems that Romney's luck has finally run out. President of the United States Barack Obama looks destined to claim victory at some point this evening or early tomorrow morning in the 2012 presidential election. Why do I have confidence?

The polling aggregates are crystal clear. [...]

The only state where they disagree is Florida, where FiveThirtyEight and HuffPollster have a small Obama edge, while Real Clear has Romney with a more comfortable lead. As of Monday night, the average of all three gives Obama 303 electoral votes to Romney's 235.

I'd have to have a very good statistical reason to disagree with the average for me go in another direction. I don't have one. I'll go with Obama 303 to Romney 235 in the electoral college as my prediction.

7.49pm GMT

The Guardian's Rory Carroll finds friends on opposite sides of the political divide in Lakewood, Colorado, creating a little oasis of civility and perspective over coffee:

Daniel Taylor, 56, and Philip Nuehring, 52, live in Jefferson county, Colorado, a swing county in a swing state, and thus have been subject to relentless attack ad barrages.

Taylor, an attorney, backs Obama. “I don't think business people should be in government running it for profit.” Nuehring, an insurance analyst, backs Romney. “He has business experience whereas Obama has just theory and college experience.”

The two friends are passionate about politics but shrug off apocalyptic warnings from each campaign about what will happen if the other side prevails.

“Both sides have some merit,” said Taylor, who clearly has not been paying enough attention to Fox and MSNBC.

“Very true,” replied Nuehring. Adding with a smile: “Though of course, my side is right.”

Rory Carroll

7.42pm GMT

The Guardian's Gary Younge visits President Obama's polling station in Chicago, where he finds Democrats to be "confident, but ever so slightly nervous":

Video by Laurence Topham

7.36pm GMT

Heh.

7.35pm GMT

The Guardian's Ed Pilkington has traveled to Greenville, Ohio, a small town in the rural conservative heartlands of the state.

This is Mitt Romney country to its core, or should be. Except when I talk to people who've just come out of the polling station they seem to have been more driven by anger than support for any candidate.

George Mittermann, 82, came to the US from Hungary in 1957, a year after the Soviet invasion. Sporting a USA hat and a T-shirt that says "Proud to be an American", he has voted for Romney, but not because he likes the man but because he doesn't want America to become a communist state.

"I came from a Communist country, I don't want America to become one. That's Obama's attitude. Take away from the rich. Why he want to do that - rich people give us jobs. It's just like in Hungary - first they take away from the rich, then they come after you."

Mona Turner, a retired bus driver aged 64, voted for Romney because she was angry about Obama's lies. "There were so many, I can't deal with that. I know all politicians lie, but his were blatant."

Nancy Welbaum voted for Romney because she was angry that Obama wanted to take away her guns. A factory worker, she goes target shooting with a .22 rifle and a 9mm pistol. "Obama, Hillary Clinton, they all want to take away our gun rights."

Trevyn French, 24, was so angry towards both Obama and Romney that he did something different - he voted for the Libertarian candidate Gary Johnson. He said he likes Johnson's emphasis on giving power back to individual states, and his plan to legalise marijuana.

French's girlfriend, Carol James, had the most original approach of any Ohioan voter I've met so far. She's so angry about both main presidential candidates that she just stuck out her pen and voted for anyone else on the voting form. She doesn't even know which candidate she voted for, other than that it wasn't Romney or Obama. "Everything's a mess," she said. "I don't like either of them, but I knew I had to vote so I could complain about whichever one wins."

Ed Pilkington

7.28pm GMT

Want to Instagram your ballot? Be careful where you do it, the Guardian's Katie Rogers writes:

We've seen a great number of sepia-toned ballots, voting lines and voting machines so far today, but you might want to think twice before applying that Sierra filter. In some states, snapping a photo from the polls can land you in legal trouble. 

Indeed, in North Carolina, there are laws on the books prohibiting photo and video of the polls.

The Citizen Media Law project has compiled this handy list of state-by-state recording regulations and is using the hashtag #DocTheVote to get the word out. The organization has also compiled this video explainer about how to record your polling experience without landing in the slammer:

An Associated Press report said Fox News host Sean Hannity may have broken the law by tweeting a photo of his ballot. Gizmodo also has posted a guide explaining the legalese.

Katie Rogers

Updated at 7.31pm GMT

7.17pm GMT

'Good deal of confusion' about Pennsylvania's voter ID rules

Signs at some polling places in central Pennsylvania misleadingly inform voters they need photo IDs to vote.

The Guardian's Erin McCann tapped an inside source to get the scoop – her father, who ripped some of the signs at a Snyder County site down.:

Pennsylvania's Republican-controlled legislature did pass a voter ID law, but on October 2 a court ruled that the law would not apply for today's election. A state judge ordered that while poll workers can still ask voters for ID, they must allow those without ID to vote. The details are here.

It's unclear how widespread the problem is. The Philadelphia Inquirer reports a "good deal of confusion":

The Committee of Seventy election watchdog agency said one of the biggest problems in the city and suburban Philadelphia counties was poll workers telling voters that they needed to have voter ID before they could cast ballots.

"There's a lot of honest misunderstanding, and maybe some not so honest," said Zack Stalberg, the committee's CEO. "There's a good deal of confusion." [...]

Stalberg said there numerous polling sites across the region that were handing out old information saying that voters needed to produce identification for the current election.

"There are reports from all over, both the city and the suburbs," Stalberg said, adding that his organization would try to determine whether the problems was part of any voter suppression effort.

Updated at 7.19pm GMT

7.04pm GMT

Let's hear from Jim Newell, who's in Virginia, one of the battleground states that Romney needs to win if he's to have a hope of clinching the White House.

Arlington County, at the tip-top of Virginia just across the Potomac River from Washington DC, is one of the several dense and growing counties in Northern Virginia that President Obama will need to maximize his support in if he wants to carry the commonwealth for a second time. 

While the neighborhoods are older here than they are in some of the ever-growing exurban counties surrounding it, Arlington has benefitted from the same influx of young, educated workers attracted to the security of government or government contracting careers, which have been plentiful in the post-9/11 security boom. What's to complain about? Arlington has got it made! 

But will its citizens reward President Obama with that sweet, sweet 70+ percent of the county vote that he so desires?

Arlington precinct 001, at Peyton Randolph Elementary School, opened at 6am. When I showed up shortly before noon, the precinct volunteer estimated that about 740 or so voters had already come and gone. 

The voters in line seemed to represent an accurate cross-section of diverse, booming Arlington: the middle-aged white folks who've lived in the same nearby houses for decades, young professionals, African-Americans, and a prominent Indian and Southeast Asian community. An Indian family outside the gym was manning a table with homemade chicken recipes and basmati rice for the exhausted voters who'd just completed their grueling exercise of democratic rights.

Ahmad Fadel, an African immigrant who's lived in the area for two or three years and works in a hotel, voted for Romney. Take that, stereotypes! While he's a registered independent, and he voted for the Democrat in the last governor's race, this time it's "all that stuff out there" that's guiding him towards Romney. "All the abortion," he clarified.

Stephen Reed, 26, works for Arlington County's department of parks and recreations. He voted for Obama, but also for Republican George Allen in the state's tight Senate race. He didn't like the nasty tone of Democrat Tim Kaine's ads. Reed feels that Obama's done okay with the situation he was put into, and now he's on "the verge" of a blossoming economy -– something he deserves to reap the benefits of. 

The Obama campaign is hoping that in big blue Northern Virginia, Reed's attitude prevails.

Updated at 7.05pm GMT

6.52pm GMT

This video of an apparently malfunctioning voting machine in Pennsylvania has been much shared today, but we have held off publishing it until the story had been confirmed.

NBC News says it has now established the machine has been taken off line. Conspiracy theory alert: the video shows an attempted vote for Barack Obama being registered as one for Mitt Romney.

UPDATE: The machine has been recalibrated and placed back into use, Mother Jones reports.

The YouTube user who posted the video also gave an explanation of what happened.

My wife and I went to the voting booths this morning before work. There were 4 older ladies running the show and 3 voting booths that are similar to a science fair project in how they fold up. They had an oval VOTE logo on top center and a cartridge slot on the left that the volunteers used to start your ballot.

I initially selected Obama but Romney was highlighted. I assumed it was being picky so I deselected Romney and tried Obama again, this time more carefully, and still got Romney. Being a software developer, I immediately went into troubleshoot mode. I first thought the calibration was off and tried selecting Jill Stein to actually highlight Obama. Nope. Jill Stein was selected just fine. Next I deselected her and started at the top of Romney's name and started tapping very closely together to find the 'active areas'. From the top of Romney's button down to the bottom of the black checkbox beside Obama's name was all active for Romney. From the bottom of that same checkbox to the bottom of the Obama button (basically a small white sliver) is what let me choose Obama. Stein's button was fine. All other buttons worked fine.

I asked the voters on either side of me if they had any problems and they reported they did not. I then called over a volunteer to have a look at it. She him hawed for a bit then calmly said "It's nothing to worry about, everything will be OK." and went back to what she was doing. I then recorded this video.

There is a lot of speculation that the footage is edited. I'm not a video guy, but if it's possible to prove whether a video has been altered or not, I will GLADLY provide the raw footage to anyone who is willing to do so. The jumping frames are a result of the shitty camera app on my Android phone, nothing more.

Updated at 7.55pm GMT

6.41pm GMT

Republican strategist Liz Mair paints a gloomy picture for Romney in her election prediction, handing Obama the key states of Nevada, Colorado, Wisconsin, Ohio and Pennsylvania (where Romney was due to campaign even today).

Her prediction would give Obama 280 electoral college votes, 10 ahead of the winning line. Here's her prediction visualised with the Guardian's Balloons of Polling™.

6.28pm GMT

As usual, there will be battle among the TV networks for the Election Gimmick Award. CNN looks to be well ahead on the gimmick-o-meter with its plan to use the lights on the Empire State Building in New York to demonstrate the results. Blue and red bars will snake up the tower as states are called. And then CNN projects a result, the top of the tower will turn red or blue. We can't imagine how excited Wolf Blitzer will be about this.

6.17pm GMT

Residents on Sandy-ravaged Staten Island have been voting in challenging conditions. At this school, piles of donated clothing are sorted, while voters cast their ballots inside. Photographer Julie S Demansky says the volume of people was light.

6.16pm GMT

Chris McGreal is in Tampa, Florida, where the sun has finally emerged after a rainy morning:

At the C. Blythe Andrews Jr. public library, where very long lines formed for early voting last week, Larry du Pree is sporting a large glitzy - some might say gaudy - watch with Obama on the face. 

"In our community we kind of take this election personally. Being African American, for me to vote for Mitt Romney is like a chicken voting for Colonel Sanders," he said.

Du Pree said that some of his fellow African Americans were determined to vote because of attempts by the Republican legislature to make it more difficult.

"I call it voter suppression. They want to take us back to the slavery days," he said.

Jackie Wilson has voted and is waiting beyond the mandatory 100 feet to urge others to back Obama. She has pinned Obama badges all over her Obama T-shirt, and has a "Republicans for Obama" sticker on her car. She says it annoys Romney supporters more than a plain old Obama bumper sticker.

Republicans are not her favourite people.

"Look at the things Republicans say, like: Take our country back. This is a country of immigrants. Every single one of us is an immigrant including those Republicans. The only people who aren't are Native Americans. So if anyone should be taking their country back it's Native Americans," she said.

Another voter introduced himself as Booker T Washington. When I looked sceptical he presented his veteran's card. He served in Vietnam and is still grumpy about only being paid $71 a month by the US army back then.

"This is a pretty important election. It's about whether we want to have people trying to keep other people in a down situation," he said.
Did he vote for Obama?

"I sure did. Not because he's a black man and I'm a black man. I vote for him because what he says is better for all of us. It has nothing to do with his colour," he said.

Chris McGreal

Updated at 6.18pm GMT

6.01pm GMT

Summary

A lunchtime summary:

• Voting is under way, and there are lines to prove it. The first polling stations close at 6pm ET. The bulk of the results are expected to come in closer to midnight in the east than to sunset.

• Our correspondents have spoken with voters and taken the measure of the race at polling stations in the battleground states of Florida, New Hampshire, Ohio, Iowa, Wisconsin, Colorado and Nevada.

• A misleading robocall was attributed to a county elections office in Florida. The call told voters they could cast ballots tomorrow.

• Some voters in New York and New Jersey are trying out new emergency voting procedures in the wake of Hurricane Sandy.

• Time is growing short for you to predict how the electoral college will shake out using our Balloons of Polling electoral tracker. Also be sure to read our animated graphic novel telling the story of the campaign.

Updated at 6.21pm GMT

5.44pm GMT

The Republican ticket is on its way to an appearance in Cleveland, Ohio. Here's Romney aide Garrett Jackson:

5.35pm GMT

Republican vice presidential nominee Paul Ryan voted this morning in his hometown of Janesville, Wisconsin. The Guardian's Suzanne Goldenberg is there:

It's one thing to roll out of bed on election day, and head straight for the polling station after dropping the kids at school, without a thought to what you've got on. It's another when you vote in Janesville, Paul Ryan's hometown, and there are enough television cameras trained on the line as a red carpet runway.

“All of a sudden there was a bunch of cameras set up,” said Melissa Crider, mother of five, who turned up to vote with her equally flummoxed friend Amy Tomlin. “I thought to myself: 'I didn't sign up for his. Maybe I should just go back in line and wait'.”

“If I'd know he was going to be here I definitely would not have come dressed in the clothes I dropped the kids off to school in,” said Tomlin.

There was already a sizeable line in front of the room set aside for voting at the Janesville public library when Paul Ryan turned up to cast his vote a little before 9am: Crider and Tomlin, a nun who later exited the library with a DVD of the Wizard of Oz tucked under arm and two women arguing loudly and angrily about the various merits of contestants on last night's edition of The Voice.

Ryan, who is running for re-election to his seat in Congress as well as for vice-president, went straight to the front of the line – not that Crider held it against him. “To be honest, he seemed a little embarrassed by it,” she said. “I think he was blushing,” Tomlin said.

The near-encounter might have been even more awkward if Ryan knew that Crider, who lives around the corner, didn't vote for him or Mitt Romney.

You can read more of Suzanne's report here.

5.30pm GMT

Robocall tells Florida voters they can vote tomorrow

The Miami Herald reports that the elections office in Pinellas county, Florida mistakenly made robocalls to thousands of voters telling them they have until 7pm tomorrow to vote. "The calls went out between 8 a.m. and 8:30 a.m. because of a glitch with the SOE’s phone system," the Herald reported:

Kathie Spitzer, a 55-year-old St. Petersburg resident who works from home, said she got the recorded message at 8:07 a.m.

It was a recording of a woman’s voice. She identified herself as an employee with the Pinellas County Supervisor of Elections office, Spitzer said, and she had something to tell voters.

Election Day would be tomorrow.

“She said that they would take ballots through 7 p.m. tomorrow,” Spitzer said. “I couldn’t believe it. It was very upsetting.”

Read the Herald report here.

Updated at 5.39pm GMT

5.21pm GMT

The Guardian's Rory Carroll talks with voters in Lakewood in the battleground state of Colorado (9 electoral votes):

It's a trailer park of a few dozen small, ramshackle homes tucked off West Colfax Ave. Blink and you miss it. It's also a microcosm of the white working class in Colorado's best known swing county, Jefferson.

You would think the economy would dominate how it votes today but, according to the (unrepresentative) sample I spoke to, not so.

“I don't believe a word Romney says,” says Samantha Angerman, 24, a massage therapist, standing by a crumbling fence with two barking dogs. “He wants to take away women's rights. I”m voting for Obama.”

Her partner, Chris Penwell, 33, also a massage therapist, was plumping for Romney because the federal government was meddling too much in the states. Plus there was that rumour about Obama not being American. “It bothers me that he hasn't produced certain documents.”

A few trailers up, Ana Higgins, 21, and Tristyn Webber, 18, who sell merchandise for a band, echoed Angerman's social concerns. “Romney wants to get rid of abortion. He's so stupid, so religious. It'd be like having a Catholic priest for president. No way!” said Webber.

On the corner, Lisa Burkheimer, 44, who is partially deaf, on disability benefit and thus part of the 47%, was voting for Obama but said she wouldn't sweat it he lost. “If Romney wins I'll be bummed out but that's OK, you can't win them all.”

Rory Carroll

5.14pm GMT

The president gets out the vote in Wisconsin.

5.12pm GMT

What's more boring: standing on line – or looking at pictures of people standing on line?

Election day, wonderfully, is all about lines. The key to admiring them is to consider what they represent. Cox Radio reporter Jamie Dupree is re-tweeting a lot of voting-line photos today:

BuzzFeed has found a way to have fun with these photos. They've put together a photo quiz of people in line at the airport and people in line to vote.

Test your skills at discerning whether that look in those line-standers' eyes is the steely determination to participate in their democracy – or a steely resignation at whatever crazy new routine the TSA has come up with.

4.38pm GMT

The Guardian's Adam Gabbatt is in Manchester, New Hampshire, where he interviews voters as they exit a polling station. Some well-spoken voters up there in New Hampshire:

Adam Gabbatt

4.34pm GMT

At President Obama's rally in Columbus, Ohio, yesterday, Jay-Z reworked his hit "99 problems." In the new version, he dismisses "Mitt" Romney, instead of "bitch"(es). Here's the video if you missed it:

Updated at 4.39pm GMT

4.30pm GMT

The Guardian's Dominic Rushe reports that Wall Street is pretty flat this morning as investors wait it out:

While we wait Jack Ablin, chief investment officer at BMO, has been working out how companies in the swing states have fared under Obama compared to the wider stock market.

Interestingly, all of the states in play today have outpaced the S&P 500 over the last four years. Thanks to a whopping 683% gain in Las Vegas Sands and some successful gold mining operations, Nevada leads the pack with a 58 percent annualized return. It will be interesting to see how the swing states will vote today. If stock market returns influence elections, Obama will be helped.

Dominic Rushe

4.24pm GMT

The Guardian's Katie Rogers observes that Ohioans just can't catch a moment to themselves:

As the much-courted voters attempt to cast their ballots in the battleground state to end all battlegrounds, a blimp that bears the slogan "America Needs Romney" has appeared in the skies over Columbus:

No word if it's the exact blimp that crash landed in Davie, Fla. back in October, but according to the dirigible's Twitter feed, it made the journey from the Sunshine State to Ohio around Nov. 3.

“I thought boy, Mitt Romney really wants us to vote for him," Teri Balter told NBC when the aircraft was spotted deflating overhead. 

Katie Rogers

4.07pm GMT

The Guardian's Paul Harris is in Des Moines, Iowa, where voters woke up to a cold morning of drizzle and sleet in some parts and thick, low grey clouds, he writes:

In the Des Moines suburb of Highland Park - a middle class area that is a mix of Republican and Democratic voters - there was a steady stream of voters into a local church.

Josh Ervasti, who works in finance, was voting for Mitt Romney and got caught in a, perhaps, Freudian slip. "I am voting Mitt because I think we need to take the company in a better direction. I mean, country. We need someone with a lot more competence running the country," he said. For him economic issues were central. "Social issues are important, but I am not voting on them. It is the economy that matters. We need to get back to growth again," he said.

Meanwhile, retiree Barbara Meeks was having none of that. She was remaining loyal to President Barack Obama and had no time for the closing and controversial Republican argument that Romney was now a symbol of change. "I think he has done a wonderful job. There has been real change, change for teachers and help for the elderly. He has done a lot for people," said the 68-year-old.

But neither was entirely confident of victory in Iowa. "We have a good chance," said Meeks.

"I really think it's going to be neck-and-neck. I just do not know," said Ervasti.

Paul Harris

3.56pm GMT

From the Comments: The Guardian's Ruth Spencer has been chatting with some voters in Ohio (whose locations we've verified), the first of which is from a county we know well, Clark County:

A dispatch from Ohio resident ClarkCounty:

I live in New Carlisle (a town of about 7k) in Clark County. I voted early, as did 30% of registered voters in my county. My friends on Facebook reported lines forming at 6:30am (when the polls open). I drove past a polling location at 7am and the parking lot was packed. The average wait here seems to be about an hour...which surprising because we are a rather rural area.

ClarkCounty has also been taking all kinds of Ohio-related questions from readers in this thread for the last hour. Here's what he's taught us about Ohio so far:

The state song is Hang On Sloopy.
Beards are making a comeback.

Another Ohio dispatch came from CitizenCarrier:

I'm in the east Columbus neighborhood called "Old Towne East". There was no line at 8:30 AM. I estimate turnaround to be at or just under 10 minutes. There were lines, from what a man passing out Democrat voting guides told me, from 6:30 to 7:30 as people sought to vote before going to work. My local AM radion station, 610 WTVN, has been reporting that as the norm pretty much everywhere else in the city.

Ruth Spencer

3.39pm GMT

The Guardian's Chris McGreal is in Florida.

3.31pm GMT

Daniel Hernandez is in Nevada, where polls are now open and Romney looks like an underdog, if not a longshot:

Since 56 percent of Nevadans have already cast their ballots... a survey taken over the weekend by Public Policy Polling showed Obama with a 4 point lead. This being a gambling town, it's also worth noting that sportsbetting shops have Obama as the solid favorite here. So the odds are simply not in Romney's favor.

Nevertheless, the Obama campaign needs to build on its lead in Las Vegas and surrounding Clark County to cushion against Romney gains in rural areas and Reno in the north, where the GOP is favored. They are relying on unions like the SEIU and Culinary Workers Union 226, which represents casino workers on the Strip, to help get out the vote. Democratic insiders told me yesterday the SEIU is ahead of its goals but Culinary 226, "unfortunately," is still mobilizing its rank and file.

The Nevada GOP meanwhile has improved its ground game since 2008, when Obama beat McCain by 12 points. With a Mormon candidate on top of the ticket, they expect to get a boost from LDS church, having told CNN this summer that a "flood" of Mormon volunteers would arrive from Utah and California on election day to get out the vote for Mitt.

Daniel Hernandez

Updated at 3.40pm GMT

3.19pm GMT

President Obama will deliver one of two very different speeches from this lectern tonight.*

* Assuming we have a winner tonight.

3.14pm GMT

It looks like the weather in Florida is icky (?!?), it's cold and dark in Iowa, sheepishly sunny in Ohio. How does weather affect turnout? The Guardian's Forecaster Harry Enten has the answer:

Bad weather actually does drive down voter participation. For every inch above normal rainfall, overall turnout drops by a little less than 1%, but Democratic turnout drops by 2.5%. Every inch above average snowfall decreases turnout by 0.5%. Since the water equivalent of 10 inches of snow usually equals an inch of rain, it's more likely snow will effect an election. [...]

Florida is the one state where rain could change have more an impact. There will be showers in the northern half of the state including the key I-4 corridor. Even so, the race would have to be about a point to a point and a half tighter than polling average for the weather to have an effect.

Harry takes a more in-depth look at the forecasts for different parts of 10 swing states here.

3.08pm GMT

The Guardian's Ed Pilkington is in Cheviot, Ohio, a suburb of Cincinnati in Hamilton county in the south-west of the state:

Carol Ann McIlmurray, 56, is precisely the kind of person Romney needs to attract in large numbers here today. She has just voted for Romney, even though in 2008 she went for Obama.

Why the switch? "I voted for Obama in 2008 because I wanted change. But our country is in such peril right now. We gave him his chance, he's had four years to prove himself, but our little town is in peril. Funds are being cut from schools, from hospitals. Now it's Romney's turn."

Christy Marie, 34, a single mother with a three-year-old child, had voted a second time for Obama. Why? "I can't vote for a platform that sees women as second-class citizens. I work in a real estate office where I do better work than the men but am paid less than them. That's not right. Obama has fought for us and kept unemployment levels down, whereas Romney would ban abortions and that would lead to twice as many deaths as women would keep having them."

This is the 2012 presidential election in a nut-shell. It's a toss up between the McIlmurrays and the Maries. Watch this space.

Ed Pilkington

Updated at 3.40pm GMT

2.54pm GMT

At his concert last night, recording artist Bob Dylan predicted a "landslide" Barack Obama victory in today's election. The AP reports:

Dylan spoke to the Madison [Wisconsin] audience as he was wrapping up his concert that came just hours after Obama appeared at a morning rally in the same city with rocker Bruce Springsteen.

Dylan made his comments during his encore when he said, "We tried to play good tonight since the president was here today."

He went on to say he thinks Obama will prevail Tuesday.

Dylan says, "Don't believe the media. I think it's going to be a landslide."

After his comments, Dylan completed the song to the roar of the crowd.

(h/t: @GrahamDavidA)

2.48pm GMT

Due to damage from Hurricane Sandy, there are two big changes to the way voters in two states will cast ballots this year.

In New Jersey, people can vote by e-mail or fax. That's unprecedented, and certain to be the subject of much skeptical review. If it appears to have worked well, it could hasten the arrival of universal Internet voting. In 2008, New Jersey voted for Obama 57-42 over McCain.

In New York (63-36 Obama in 2008) the situation is potentially more confusing. Governor Andrew Cuomo announced that voters in districts hit hard by Sandy can vote in adjacent districts.

The problem is that ballots in those adjacent districts may not include local races.

The governor says people's votes will count for the presidential race or the U.S. Senate race, Ken Lovett of the NY Daily News reports, But a person’s vote won’t count if they are voting at a site that is not their home state Senate or Assembly district.

“It’s fair,” [Governor Cuomo] said. “You can’t vote for a race that you’re not eligible to vote for.”

“It’s a difficult situation,” he said. “The Board of Elections appears to be working hard to do everything they can. But you have people who are displaced. We’re trying to do the best we can. We want to allow everyone to vote and make it easy as possible.”

Updated at 3.10pm GMT

2.38pm GMT

The first polls close tonight at 6pm ET in Indiana and Kentucky (some polling stations stay open till 7pm in both states, which straddle time zones). Shortly thereafter the television networks and cable stations will start projecting winners.

But how do the people on TV know who won? Who is giving information to the people giving us information?

ABC News' Rick Klein explains that it's a combination of exit polling and precincts officially reporting:

The exit polls provide the first indication of who will win the election, but those results will be under tight lock down until 5 p.m. The exit poll analysts are literally quarantined in a room and restricted from phone and computer use until that magic hour when the second wave of exit poll data will be released. And then, the feast begins.

The exit polls provide a wealth of information about who voted, ranging from where they voted to whom they voted for to why. But as exciting as that first rush of information is after a long day of fasting, the initial exit poll data is only the tip of the iceberg. A lot of the information will change as the polls begin to close at 7 p.m. EST and the first votes are counted.

As the vote tallies roll in to the ABC Decision Desk, these numbers will be compared to the exit polls, as well as other data, and the state-by-state projections will begin. Once either candidate reaches 270 electoral votes, the winner will be projected. But that moment is not likely to come any time sooner than 11 p.m. EST tonight, and it's possible that, as happened in 2000, there won't be a definitive decision by election night's end!

For your reference our handy state-by-state table of poll closure times is here.

2.24pm GMT

Here's a handy election day resource: Katie Rogers has gathered the Guardian correspondents and editors who will be tweeting news about the election into a handy Guardian US Election 2012 Twitter list. Give us a follow, we'll tell you what we know.

Updated at 2.39pm GMT

2.14pm GMT

How the candidates are spending the day

First of all, they're all going to vote, with the exception of President Obama, who became the first president in history to vote early when he cast his ballot on 25 October.

Governor Romney and running mate Paul Ryan will campaign in Cleveland, Ohio, and Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, before making their way to Boston for a party tonight at the Boston Convention & Exhibition Center.

President Obama plans to "relax" in Chicago with a mere dozen interviews with TV and radio stations in swing states, encouraging people to go vote. He also plans to play his lucky election day game of basketball.

The Bidens head to Chicago later this morning to join the Obamas, CBS president-tracker Mark Knoller reports. The Obama party tonight is at Chicago’s McCormick Place convention center.

The Bidens voted this morning in Greenville, Deleware.

Before voting this morning, Mitt Romney took out the trash, his personal aide Garrett Jackson tweets. Painfully obvious metaphor alert, anyone?

Updated at 2.18pm GMT

2.05pm GMT

A list of our far-flung correspondents and their locations:

Ed Pilkington is in Ohio
Paul Harris is in Iowa
Suzanne Goldenberg is in Wisconsin
Chris McGreal is in Florida
Rory Carroll is in Colorado
Adam Gabbatt is in New Hampshire
Daniel Hernandez is in Nevada

Jim Newell in Virginia

UPDATE:

We ought to have mentioned our planned coverage for tonight's victory/concession parties. Gary Younge is in Chicago to cover Obama, and Jonathan Freedland is in Boston to cover Romney.

Updated at 3.16pm GMT

2.01pm GMT

The Romneys have arrived to vote at their polling place in Belmont, Massachusetts. Ari Shapiro is NPR's man on the scene:

1.55pm GMT

The Guardian's Richard Adams is going to blog all of the election results tonight. Last night he caught the first two precincts to report: Dixville Notch, New Hampshire, whose residents vote immediately after midnight; and Hart's Location, NH, which boasts 33 voters. Richard reported last night at midnight:

In Dixville Notch, we have the presidential vote from the 10 electors, and the precinct captain announces:

This has never happened before in Dixville, we have a tie, five votes each.

Now there's an omen for America. Except that Dixville has two registered Democrats, three registered Republicans, and five registered independents. So, ah, Obama won indies 60% to 40%.

The second oddball early voting location is tiny Hart's Location in New Hampshire – and it went for Barack Obama. Obama won 23 votes, Romney got 9 and Libertarian candidate Gary Johnson received one vote.

For those who want to know, in 2008 it was Obama 17, McCain 10.

So aggregating Dixville Notch and Hart's Location: Obama 28, Romney 14, Johnson 1. That's the official tally so far.

So what's up with Hart's Location? Explained, via AP:

Hart's Location began the early-bird voting tradition in 1948. Most residents of the White Mountain village then were railroad workers who had to be on the job during normal polling hours. By 1964 the townspeople had grown weary of the media attention and the late hours and did away with the practice. They revived it in 1996.

Richard Adams

Updated at 2.09pm GMT

1.45pm GMT

Guardian animation expert Greg Chen, politics blogger Richard Adams and copy editor Erin McCann have collaborated on a stunning animated graphic novel telling the story of the campaign. It's called America: Elect! The action-packed journey to US election day.

Check it out. It's a feast for the eyes and 100% scrollable. Now if you'll pardon us – we're going to go watch it again.

Updated at 1.48pm GMT

1.31pm GMT

Florida

And over to Florida, where Chris McGreal is berthed – and they're actually experiencing non-sunny weather.

Both parties are predicting a turnout to match 2008 in Florida – in part because of anger among some Obama supporters at the lengths the state's Republican legislature has gone to to discourage them from voting. 

Some measures, such as the voter photo identification law and a virtual ban on civic groups registering voters, were struck down by federal courts. But others were allowed to stand, including the cutting of the number of days for early voting which contributed to the huge queues that meant some people waited more than eight hours to cast a ballot. 

The Republicans say the new measures were necessary to combat fraud. But as the American Civil Liberties Union has noted, more people are attacked by sharks in Florida than convicted of election fraud. That has helped fire up some of the president's supporters who see Florida's Republican party machinations as trampling on their democratic rights. 

But many Republicans who declined to vote for John McCain four years ago because he was not conservative enough, care less about the candidate they will be supporting this time than the opportunity to get rid of Obama. The place to watch – and where I will be – is Hillsborough county, around the Tampa area. Where it goes, Florida goes. In 2004, George Bush won the county by 3%. Four years later, Obama took it by the same margin. 

The polling stations are likely to be less of an ordeal for voters, in part because there are many more polling stations on election day proper than for early voting. The weather's horrible though. After weeks of sunshine, suddenly it's grey and raining. Not the best day for standing in line. Perhaps the Republicans control the weather too.

Chris McGreal in Tampa

Updated at 1.34pm GMT

1.25pm GMT

Ohio

Let's check in with our reporters in two key battleground states: first here's Ed Pilkington in Ohio.

Election day has arrived in Ohio, the state that many pontificators have marked down as the battleground state above all others to watch. What happens here today could well determine the outcome of the whole presidential race: Mitt Romney really needs to win this state if he is to have a chance of unseating Barack Obama from the White House.

I'm going to spend today on a triangular journey through the electoral landscape of one large section of the state to sample its diversity of political complexion. There's going to be a lot of driving involved across Ohio's monotonously flat plains, but I'll be counting on country music and the rants of Rush Limbaugh on talk radio to keep me going.

First stop is a suburb of Cincinnati, one of Romney's most crucial target areas and where Obama campaigned Sunday (see picture below). This area is traditionally very conservative, the heartland of Ohio's God-fearing, straight-living south-western people. But in 2008 Obama became only the second Democratic presidential candidate to win in Hamilton county in which Cincinnati is situated since Lyndon Johnson in 1964.

After that, it's a two-hour drive due north to Greenville, a country town in the rural west of Ohio. This is pure Republican country, dependable and unwavering. McCain swept Darke county in which Greenville is located by a resounding 68% to Obama's 30%.

The outcome here is not in doubt – for such a deep red county to turn blue would require a magician to pour some potent liberal potion into the local drinking water. But it will be interesting to see how dyed-in-the-wool conservatives are feeling about Romney's prospects, and the future of the country if he loses tonight.

Then I will cut across country due east to the state capital, Columbus. The city is very mixed politically. It has a buzzing university scene as home to Ohio state university, which lends it a lot of Democratic-voting young people. In 2008 Obama won Franklin county around Columbus handsomely, by 59% to McCain's 40%.

But the city also acts as the state's main financial centre and has a deep conservative tradition. I'll go to a polling station in a northern suburb, where political opinion is very mixed to take soundings there about which way the wind is blowing.

Ed Pilkington in Cincinnati

1.23pm GMT

Summary

• Long polling lines have formed across the country, with reports of hour-plus waits in Ohio, Florida and elsewhere – including Washington, DC. Here's a snapshot from what looks like a soggy morning in Jacksonville, Florida:

• The early vote count at the dawn of election day stood at 31,999,607 having cast their ballots, either by mail or in person. About 133m total ballots were cast in 2008.

• A final round of swing-state polling yesterday looked good for Obama, who finished strong in national polls as well. We'll see if they were right.

• Barack Obama is spending the day in his home state of Illinois. And while he has no scheduled campaign events, the hustle for votes hasn't stopped: he has about a dozen TV interviews scheduled.

• Mitt Romney dropped in two unexpected extra campaign events today. Breaking with convention – although not the law – he will speak in airport stops in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania and Cleveland, Ohio.

Updated at 1.30pm GMT

12.33pm GMT

It begins

Good morning! And welcome to our election day live blog. After 523 days on the trail for Mitt Romney, 101 campaign rallies for Barack Obama and more than $6bn in campaign spending from all directions, the day has finally arrived. About 100 million Americans are going to enter a booth or lean over a machine and vote today (nearly 32 million have voted already). With any luck we'll know who the winner is sometime tonight.

Every presidential election is significant. That's true of this one, only more so. The candidates have described sharply contrasting plans to strengthen the economy, secure the nation and attack the debt. They are beholden to constituencies with radically different visions of what an ideal American society would look like, what rights it would guarantee and what laws it would enforce. Apart from the alma mater they share, the candidates differ in their life stories and as men, in their casts of mind, in their approaches to problems and to people. Both are outsiders, in their ways. After today's election, the story of each man will be rewritten for good. As will the country's.

Our correspondents are on the ground in eight battleground states to cover the action at the polls. We'll be talking to voters all day long to find out how they cast their ballots and why. We'll watch out for polling station delays or irregularities. We'll also keep an eye on the campaigns as team Obama hunkers down in Chicago and team Romney skips from Cleveland to Pittsburgh to Boston.

The first polls close tonight at 6pm ET and we'll be bringing you comprehensive coverage of the results as they come in. Polls close in the key swing state of Ohio at 7.30 pm ET, although results out of there are not likely to be announced until hours later. A list of poll closure times is here.

Who do you think is going to win the race to 270 electoral votes – and what will the final result be? Our electoral tracker shows Obama with 247 "safe" electoral votes and Romney with 191. There are eight states up for grabs, in our model. Think you know which way Ohio will go, or Florida? Test your predictions on the Guardian's special interactive tool – the Balloons of Polling – and send your prediction to your friends and enemies.

Election day is here. May the best candidate win. 

Updated at 1.09pm GMT
